    Dithiocarbazate-Copper Complexes for Bioimaging and Treatment of Pancreatic Cancer

    • Yi Gou
      Yi Gou
      Laboratory of Respiratory Disease, Affiliated Hospital of Guilin Medical University, Guilin 541001, Guangxi, China
      More by Yi Gou
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-2900-4983
      • ,

      MeiRong Chen

    SUBJECTS:

    • Group 11 complexes
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Anticancer agents that present nonapoptotic cell death pathways are required for treating apoptosis-resistant pancreatic cancer. Here, we synthesized three fluorescent dithiocarbazate–copper complexes, {[CuII(L)(Cl)] 1, [CuII2(L)2(NO3)2] 2, and [CuII2CuI(L)2(Br)3] 3}, to assess their antipancreatic cancer activities. Complexes 1–3 showed significantly greater cytotoxicity toward several pancreatic cancer cell lines with better IC50 than those of the HL ligand and cisplatin. Confocal fluorescence imaging showed that complex 3 was primarily localized in the mitochondria. Primarily, compound 3 also can be applied to in vivo imaging. Further studies revealed that complex 3 kills pancreatic cancer cells by triggering multiple mechanisms, including ferroptosis. Complex 3 is the first copper complex to evoke cellular events consistent with ferroptosis in cancer cells. Finally, it significantly retarded the ASPC-1 cells’ growth in a mouse xenograft model.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Studies conducted by Matrisian et al. revealed that in Western countries, pancreatic cancer would be the second leading cause of cancer death in the next decade.(1) It is the most malignant cancer and has an inferior prognosis, with a 5 year survival rate currently lower than 5%.(2) Contrary to the steady increase in most cancers’ survival rate, the progress in pancreatic cancer treatment has been slow.(3) Surgical resection remains the only viable option for long-term survival, but less than one in five patients receive surgical treatment due to local vascular metastasis or invasion.(4) Therefore, pancreatic cancer treatment, especially advanced pancreatic cancer, depends on systemic chemotherapy.(5)
    As early as 1996, gemcitabine monotherapy was approved by the FDA as the standard of care for pancreatic cancer. Still, this treatment yields an overall 5 year survival rate of only 6.7%, one of the lowest of all cancer types.(6) Currently, two combination regimens with modest clinical activity, FOLFIRINOX (a combination of oxaliplatin, 5-fluoruracil, folinic acid, and irinotecan) and nab-paclitaxel/gemcitabine(7,8) have emerged as options for patients with pancreatic cancer. However, they are associated with substantial toxic side effects, such as neutropenia.(9) Hence, effective therapeutics for antipancreatic cancer chemotherapy are urgently needed.
    Metal-based agents exhibit potential for cancer treatment, presenting the possibility of unique drug action mechanisms through the rational selection of the central metal, the complex’s kinetic properties, the metal oxidation state, the number and type of ligands, and the coordination geometry adopted.(10) Copper, as an essential micronutrient for all organisms, plays crucial roles in critical biological functions, such as oxygen transport, energy metabolism, melanin synthesis, cell signaling, and enzyme activity.(11) Furthermore, cancer cells and tissues take up more copper than normal cells. Thus, copper metabolism has been implicated in tumor metastasis, angiogenesis, and growth.(12,13)
    Dithiocarbazate Schiff-base ligands, whose general structures are analogous to tridentate heterocyclic thiosemicarbazone and hydrazone ligands, have gained extensive attention recently for their antiproliferative, antiamoebic, and antibacterial activities.(14,15) In many cases, small changes in the molecular structure of dithiocarbamate derivatives can lead to large differences in their biological activity.(16) Moreover, these ligands possess both soft sulfur and hard nitrogen donor atoms, which can coordinate with various metal ions to form metal complexes with interesting physicochemical and enhanced biological properties.(15) Therefore, in the medicinal inorganic chemistry field, copper complexes with dithiocarbazate Schiff-base ligands show much promise as anticancer agents for future development.
    Recently, some copper complexes have been evaluated as antipancreatic cancer agents in vitro and in vivo.(17−30) For example, Sarkar et al. synthesized a 3-formylchromone Cu(II) complex with moderate antipancreatic cancer activity that induces apoptosis by inhibiting the NF-κB signaling pathway,(24) and the same authors also reported a Cu(II) complex of ketoprofen-salicylhydrazone, demonstrating that the complex has potent proapoptotic activity in COX-2 positive pancreatic cancer cells;(25) Padhye et al. synthesized a nimesulide Schiff-base Cu(II) complex and reported that it downregulates the expression of the antiapoptotic proteins Bcl-xl and Bcl-2, leading to apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells;(26) Liu et al. reported that a Cu(I)–diethyldithiocarbamate complex can induce apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells by inhibiting proteasome activity,(27) and Erxleben et al. prepared a dicopper(II) complex with moderate antipancreatic-cancer activity and confirmed that the complex interacts with cellular DNA and induces apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells.(28) Furthermore, Basha et al. presented a tolfenamic acid–Cu(II) complex that showed effects on apoptosis and G2/M cell cycle arrest by inhibiting survivin in PANC-1 cells;(29) and recently, Wang et al. reported a disulfiram–Cu(II) complex that induces autophagy-dependent apoptosis in pancreatic carcinoma cells.(30)
    Mechanistic studies of the copper complexes reported above have revealed that they realize their antipancreatic cancer activities through induction of apoptosis or apoptosis-related pathways. However, pancreatic cancer cells can easily increase their resistance to apoptosis by changing the balance of antiapoptotic and proapoptotic proteins.(31) Actually, the resistance to apoptosis has largely led to pancreatic cancer treatment failure because most anticancer therapies, such as conventional chemotherapy and radiotherapy, mainly exert their anticancer effects by triggering apoptosis of cancer cells.(32) Therefore, the synthesis of copper complexes that can kill pancreatic cancer cells by multiple mechanisms or nonapoptotic cell death pathways (such as ferroptosis) may be of great significance.
    Ferroptosis is a recognized form of controlled cell death closely related to the occurrence, progression, and treatment of tumors.(33) Ferroptosis is significantly different from apoptosis, necrosis, and autophagy regarding inducing factors, morphological characteristics, and regulatory pathways.(34) It mainly manifests as excessive oxidative stress and membrane lipid peroxidation, leading to cell death.(34) Due to its nonapoptotic nature, ferroptosis-based cancer treatments are expected to bypass the drawbacks, such as acquired apoptosis resistance, of traditional treatment methods mediated by apoptotic pathways.(35) Interestingly, cells that overexpress carcinogenic RAS (KRAS, NRAS, and HRAS) genes, such as pancreatic cancer cells with mutant KRAS genes, are more sensitive to ferroptosis.(36,37)
    Therefore, chemotherapies capable of inducing nonapoptotic cell death of pancreatic cancer cells, such as ferroptosis, warrant further investigation. Here, we synthesized three fluorescent copper complexes with the dithiocarbazate Schiff-base ligand {[CuII(L)(Cl)] 1, [CuII2(L)2(NO3)2] 2, and [CuII2CuI(L)2(Br)3] 3, where HL is methyl 2-(di(pyridin-2-yl)methylene)hydrazinecarbodithioate} to evaluate the ability of antipancreatic cancer. Notably, the copper(I/II) complex 3 displayed an interesting mechanism that can induce pancreatic cancer cells’ ferroptosis.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Characterization of Copper Complexes

    In many cases, anions can affect the crystal structure through the subtle tuning effect of their structural geometries as bonds or their bonding abilities or both to metal ions.(38) Here, we used different anions (Cl–, NO3–, and Br–) to obtain three copper complexes with different structures (Scheme 1).
    Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with the space group P1̅. As shown in Figure 1A, the Cu(II) center is surrounded by two nitrogen atoms [Cu1–N2 = 1.963(6) Å and Cu1–N4 = 2.026(7) Å] and one sulfur atom [Cu1–S1 = 2.2376(11) Å] of an L ligand and one Cl [Cu1–Cl1 = 2.257(2) Å] and exhibits distorted square-planar coordination geometry. In the solid-state, the monomeric units of complex 1 are arranged in dimeric structures (Figure S1A) such that the coordinated Cl of one monomeric unit interacts axially with the adjacent Cu1 center (Cu1···Cl1 = 2.833 Å). Moreover, as shown in Figure S1B, there are two minor occurrences of π···π stacking (center-to-center distances = 3.666 and 3.816 Å) in complex 1, which link adjacent dimer units into a two-dimensional three-connected net with 63 hcb topology (Figure S1C).
    The structure of complex 2 is shown in Figure 1B. The crystal structure shows that complex 2 exists as a centrosymmetric dimer in which each of the copper(II) ions adopts a five-coordinate geometry. The geometry polyhedron around the Cu1 center could be described as having a near-square-pyramidal geometry (τ = 0.067), with the copper center displaced from the S1/N2/N4/O1 basal plane (maximum displacement 0.083 Å for the N2 atom) by 0.28 Å toward the apical N3i (symmetry code i = 2 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z) atom. The longer apical bond length Cu1–N3i [2.373(2) Å] compared with the basal Cu–N distances [Cu1–N2 = 1.9704(18) Å and Cu1–N4 = 2.020(2) Å] is associated with the pseudo-Jahn–Teller effect on the Cu(II) ion.
    Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with the space group C2/c. As shown in Figure 1C, there are three Br atoms, three Cu atoms, and two mononegative tridentate L ligands. The Cu1 or Cu1i (i = −x, y, 1.5 – z) center shows +2 oxidation and adopts a square-planar coordination geometry containing a bromide anion and the negative tridentate L ligand in the basal plane. The Cu2 atom has +1 oxidation and is situated in a trigonal-planar geometry surrounded by one Br anion and two N atoms (N3 and N3i) from two L ligands. The coexistence of CuI and CuII in complex 3 indicates that the Br– anion, which has a stronger reducing ability than Cl– and NO3–, can promote the reduction of CuII to CuI. This coexistential phenomenon has been reported in a similar synthesis.(39) All the Cu(II)–N/S distances in complex 3 are similar to those found in complexes 1 and 2 and those reported in the literature for similar complexes.(40,41) In the solid state, as shown in Figure S2, the monomeric units of complex 3 link in a polymeric-chain-like fashion such that the coordinated S1 atom of one monomeric unit interacts axially with the neighboring Cu(II) center (Cu1···S1 = 2.887 Å).
    In all Cu complexes, the Cu–Npyridine distances [Cu1–N4 = 2.026(7) Å in 1, Cu1–N4 = 2.026(7) Å in 2, and Cu1–N4 = 2.026(7) Å in 3] are significantly longer than the Cu–Nimine distances [Cu1–N2 = 1.963(6) Å in 1, Cu1–N2 = 1.9704(18) Å in 2, and Cu1–N2 = 1.976(4) Å in 3], which can be attributed to the weaker π-back-bonding in the Cu–Npyridine bond compared with that in the Cu–Nimine bond.(42) Also, our results show that inorganic anions with different coordinating abilities, sizes, and geometries can affect the HL ligand’s coordination versatility, thus influencing the structures of its metal complexes, and this phenomenon has been reported elsewhere.(43)

    Magnetic Measurements

    Solid-state, variable-temperature, and magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on powder samples of complexes 1–3 at a 2–300 K range in a 1 kOe magnetic field. The temperature dependence of 1/χM (inverse molar magnetic susceptibility) and χMT (the product of the susceptibility and temperature) for complexes 1–3 are shown in Figure 2A. For 1, the data above 2 K followed the Curie–Weiss law with C = 0.42 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −2.11 K. The χMT value at 300 K is ∼0.42 cm3 mol–1, which is close to the spin-only value of 0.38 cm3 K mol–1 for a magnetic CuII ion with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0 and is relatively constant down to approximately 40 K.
    Below this temperature, it collapses to reach a minimum value of 0.21 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. For complexes 2 and 3, the data above 2 and 12 K followed the Curie–Weiss law with C = 0.83 and 0.82 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −1.06 and −4.74 K, respectively. The χMT values at 300 K are approximately 0.83 and 0.81 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, which are close to the spin-only value of 0.75 cm3 K mol–1 for two magnetic CuII ions with S = 1 and g = 2.0, and these decreases are also relatively constant down to approximately 21 and 40 K, respectively. They collapse below these temperatures to reach the minimum values of 0.51 and 0.10 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K.
    Based on these magnetic data, complexes 1 and 2 exhibit paramagnetic behavior at 2–300 K because of the long interion distance of the adjacent CuII ions (CuII···CuII = 3.528 Å in 1 and 5.287 Å in 2). While for complex 3, the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between CuII ions (CuII···CuII = 3.457 Å) should not be ignored below 12 K.

    UV–Vis and Fluorescence Spectra

    Figure 2B shows HL’s absorption spectra and its copper complexes 1–3, as recorded in H2O [10% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), v/v]. The HL ligand exhibits two intense absorption bands (∼280 and 346 nm) in a 250–700 range, which are assigned to n → π* and π → π* transitions. All the UV–vis absorption spectra of the complexes 1–3 present a low-energy absorption band at ∼413 nm, which is characteristic of metal–ligand charge transfer. The fluorescence spectra of these copper complexes along with the HL ligand were measured in water containing 10% DMSO (v/v) upon excitation at 415 nm (Figure 2C). Copper(II) is paramagnetic (d9 electronic arrangement) and can quench the fluorescence of adjacent fluorophores.(44) The Cu(II) complexes 1 and 2 show fluorescence emissions in the 450–650 nm region similar to the HL ligand, albeit with approximately two-times lower emission intensity (inset to Figure 2C). Interestingly, the fluorescence intensity of the mixed-valent copper(I/II) complex 3 is 26.6-, 58.1-, and 57.5-fold higher than those of the HL ligand, complex 1, and complex 2, respectively (Figure 2C), indicating that the presence of copper(I) in complex 3 plays an essential role in its prominent fluorescence intensity.
    From the structural perspective, the coordination [Cu2–N3 2.034(4) Å] of copper(I) in complex 3 with the pyridine group on the ligand not only increases the rigidity of the entire molecule but also hinders the photoinduced electron transfer process produced by the N3-donor of the lone pair of electrons,(45) leading to strong fluorescence. The fluorescence intensity of complex 2 is almost as low as that of complex 1 probably because the dimer complex 2 formed by the weaker Cu–N bond [Cu1–N3i 2.373(2) Å] decomposes into a monomer with a structure similar to that of complex 1 in solution. Notably, the HL ligand and its copper complexes exhibit fluorescence in the green region (450–650 nm) of the visible spectrum, which can be used for fluorescence-based bioimaging.

    In Vitro Potency

    The in vitro anticancer activities of the free ligand and complexes 1–3 were evaluated after 48 h of drug treatment using 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assays. Three human pancreatic cancer cell lines, namely, BxPc-3, ASPC-1, and PANC-1, were used for evaluation. The widely used metal-based anticancer drug cisplatin [cis-diaminedichloroplatinum(II)] was employed as a positive control. The IC50 values, which represent the concentration required to induce 50% cell viability, are summarized in Table 1.
    Table 1. IC50 (μM) Values of Copper Complexes against a Panel of Human Pancreatic Cancer Cell Lines
     cell growth inhibition, IC50 ± SD (μM)
    compoundBxPc-3ASPC-1PANC-1WI-38
    HL38.61 ± 4.0726.47 ± 3.1146.38 ± 5.2440.49 ± 4.51
    15.33 ± 0.614.39 ± 0.584.73 ± 0.486.58 ± 0.73
    20.86 ± 0.120.46 ± 0.050.73 ± 0.082.13 ± 0.24
    30.74 ± 0.080.41 ± 0.050.62 ± 0.052.06 ± 0.22
    cisplatin53.71 ± 6.1467.23 ± 6.3145.16 ± 4.9718.73 ± 2.19
    As revealed by the observed IC50 values, the IC50 values of the HL ligand were significantly higher than those of the copper complexes. Notably, all the copper complexes showed micromolar activities (0.41–5.33 μM) that are significantly better than cisplatin. The IC50 values of complex 1 in BxPc-3, ASPC-1, and PANC-1 cells are 10.1-, 15.3-, and 9.5-fold lower (p < 0.01) than those of cisplatin, respectively. The IC50 values of complex 2 are 62.4-, 146.1-, and 61.8-fold lower (p < 0.01) than those of cisplatin in BxPc-3, ASPC-1, and PANC-1 cells, respectively. Similarly, the IC50 values of complex 3 are 72.6-, 163.9-, and 72.8-fold lower (p < 0.01) than those of cisplatin in BxPc-3, ASPC-1, and PANC-1 cells, respectively.
    Based on the IC50 values, some structure–activity relationship trends between the HL ligand and its copper complexes can be established. First, in general, the HL ligand’s anticancer activity is clearly improved by coordination with copper metals. Second, the potencies of complexes 1–3 against pancreatic cancer cells followed the order 3 ≈ 2 > 1, suggesting that multinuclear copper complexes are likely to have anticancer potential than mononuclear copper complexes. Also, based on the excellent anticancer activity and fluorescent properties exhibited by complex 3, we selected this complex for further in vitro and in vivo investigation.

    Cellular and in Vivo Imaging Studies

    Cell imaging of metal-based complexes can provide useful information regarding their potential biological applications. Several metal complexes with intrinsic fluorescence, for example, Ir(III), Re(I), and Zn(II) complexes, facilitate cell imaging in living cells.(46−48) However, Cu(II) is paramagnetic and thus quenches the fluorescence of adjacent fluorophores, which prevents the application of Cu(II) complexes for cell imaging in living cells.(44) Interestingly, as shown in Figure 3A–E, the imaging capability of complex 3 in ASPC-1 cells can be observed through confocal fluorescence microscopy.
    To further investigate the distribution of complex 3 in ASPC-1 cells, we conducted additional colocalization experiments using DRAQ5 (nuclear localization), Golgi-Tracker Red (golgi localization), ER-Tracker Red (endoplasmic reticulum localization), LysoTracker Red (lysosomal localization), and MitoTracker Deep Red FM (mitochondrial localization) dyes. As shown in Figure 3A–C, the red fluorescence signals of DRAQ5, Golgi-Tracker Red, and ER-Tracker Red displayed a very poor overlap with the green fluorescence of complex 3, indicating that the copper complex does not localize in the nucleus, golgi, and endoplasmic reticulum. A small overlapping between the green fluorescence from complex 3 and the red fluorescence from LysoTracker Red was observed (Figure 3D), which confirmed that complex 3 was not primarily localized in the lysosome.
    As shown in Figure 3E, colocalization studies using MitoTracker Deep Red FM revealed merging of the green and red signals to form yellow coloration, confirming the accumulation of the copper complex in the mitochondrial region. There are significant advantages of targeting mitochondria, namely, (1) as the powerhouse for eukaryotic cells, mitochondrial dysfunction can prevent the rapid growth of cancer cells and even lead to their death; (2) anticancer agents located in mitochondria can avoid nuclear excision repair mechanisms that can restore DNA-drug addicts; and (3) the mitochondria located in tumor cells are more susceptible to mitochondrial dysfunction than those in normal cells.(42,49) Therefore, given the crucial roles of mitochondria in cancer cells, this can be considered a meaningful result.
    To evaluate the in vivo imaging capabilities of complex 3, we chose the BALB/c mouse as an animal model. A normal saline solution of complex 3 (0.2 mL, 3 mg/kg) was injected intraperitoneally into the mouse and imaged with 455–495 nm excitation and 535 nm emission. Immediately after injection, the in vivo fluorescence signal was very weak. However, after 30 min, a strong in vivo fluorescence was observed (Figure 3F), revealing the potential role of copper complexes in bioimaging, which is not limited to in vitro or live cells. After 4 h, although the in vivo fluorescence was weakened, it was still evident, indicating the long half-life circulation half-life of complex 3. Further, based on fluorescence of complex 3, the blood circulation half-life of complex 3 in BALB/c mice was calculated to be 1.52 h (Figure S3).

    Mechanism of Action of Complex 3

    Proteomics analysis is a high-resolution and high-throughput process that can provide advanced information involved in disease or biological processes at the protein level, and this knowledge is useful for revealing the underlying anticancer mechanisms of a therapeutic agent.(50) Therefore, to gain an insight into the mechanism of action of complex 3, tandem mass tag (TMT)-based proteomic analysis was conducted to investigate changes in the protein-expression profile of ASPC-1 cells under treatment with complex 3.
    After quality validation, 6262 proteins were quantified. Of these, 157 proteins differentially accumulated in the complex 3-treated group compared with the control group were observed based on the criteria: p < 0.05, ratio ≥ 1.5 (upregulated) or ratio ≤ 0.667 (downregulated). Of these differentially expressed proteins, 113 were upregulated, and 44 were downregulated. The gene ontology (GO) analysis results for the differentially expressed proteins are shown in Figure S4. Pathway analysis is the most direct way to systematically and comprehensively understand the biological processes of cells, the mechanisms or traits of diseases, and drug action mechanisms.(51) With the established root proteins as the background, we investigated the significantly enriched Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathways, which determine the signal transduction and metabolic pathways significantly affected by complex 3 treatment.
    The ten most significant pathways are the interleukin (IL)-17 signaling pathway, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic myeloid leukemia, fluid shear stress and atherosclerosis, ferroptosis, the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway, colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction, and the B-cell receptor signaling pathway (Figure 4A). Of these, three pathways are clearly associated with proliferation, differentiation, migration, and death of ASPC-1 cells, including ferroptosis, MAPK signaling pathway, and cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction.
    Ferroptosis is a recently regulated form of cell death and involves multiple pathological and physiological processes, such as cancer cell death, T-cell immunity, neurotoxicity, acute renal failure, and neurodegenerative diseases.(52) This KEGG study found that the ferroptosis pathway is induced primarily by significant upregulation of heme oxygenase 1 (HMOX1), glutamate-cysteine ligase, prion protein PRNP, and solute carrier family 7 member 11 (Figure S5). Another indication that complex 3 can exert antitumor effects via the ferroptosis pathway was obtained by Western blotting. HMOX1 and acyl-CoA synthetase long-chain family member 4 (ACSL4), key proteins involved in ferroptosis, have been reported to increase when ferroptosis occurs.(53,54) As expected, complex 3 treatment dose-dependently upregulated the protein levels of HMOX1 and ACSL4 (Figure 4B). Ferroptosis is initiated by the accumulation of iron-dependent lipid peroxidation relying on reactive oxygen species (ROS).(52) Flow cytometry analyses, therefore, were conducted to evaluate the production levels of lipid ROS. From Figure 4C we can see that complex 3 indeed induces lipid ROS production. Plenty of evidence revealed that mitochondria are involved in ferroptosis,(55) and in this study, the localization of complex 3 in the mitochondria (Figure 3E) indicates that the ferroptosis induced by complex 3 is probably mediated by the mitochondria. Morphologically, compared with normal mitochondria, mitochondria in the ferroptotic cells exhibit ultrastructural changes, such as volume reduction, reduced mitochondrial crista, increased mitochondrial membrane density, and ruptured outer mitochondrial membrane.(55) Therefore, transmission electron microscopy was applied to observe the mitochondria morphology. Compared with untreated cells, complex 3-treated cells showed ruptured and smaller mitochondria (Figure 4D), which are morphological changes of ferroptotic cells. Also, we conducted cytotoxicity studies in the presence of liproxstatin-1, a ferroptosis inhibitor.(56) Coincubation with liproxstatin-1 decreases the toxicity of complex 3 against ASPC-1 cells (Figure 4E). Altogether, these data demonstrate that complex 3 is an inducer of ferroptosis. Notably, this represents the first time a copper complex that has been demonstrated to induce ferroptosis. The ferroptosis pathway bypasses the apoptosis inhibition and can overcome apoptotic resistance.(35) Since pancreatic cancer cells exhibit strong resistance to apoptosis, inducing ferroptosis in pancreatic cancer cells provides a promising strategy.
    Owing to the important roles of MAPK signaling in tumor cells, using MAPK signaling pathways as therapeutic targets is a promising cancer treatment strategy.(57,58) This study found that the MAPK signaling pathway is disturbed by the upregulation of transcription factor AP-1 (JUN), growth arrest and DNA damage-inducible protein (GADD45B), proto-oncogene c-Fos (FOS), growth factor receptor-bound protein 2 (GRB2), heat shock 70 kDa protein 1A (HSPA1A), and NF-κB essential modulator as well as the downregulation of hepatocyte growth factor and transforming growth factor β-3 (TGFB3). Western blotting revealed that treatment of ASPC-1 cells causes a dose-dependent downregulation in the expression of TGFB3 and a dose-dependent increase in the expression of FOS (Figure 5A). Also, we investigated the phosphorylation levels of ERK (P-ERK), a key factor in the MAPK pathway.(59) The result showed the P-ERK decreased in a time-dependent manner in ASPC-1 cells. The western blotting data also agree with the proteomics finding that complex 3 activates the MAPK signaling pathway.
    The MAPK pathway is involved in various cellular functions, such as cell proliferation, metastasis, and apoptosis.(60,61) Accumulating evidence has shown that the inhibition of the ERK signaling pathway in the MAPK pathway can suppress cell metastasis and promote cell apoptosis.(62,63) We, therefore, investigated the effect of complex 3 on metastasis and apoptosis in ASPC-1 cells. Migration and invasion have been reported to initiate the metastatic process.(64) Thus, we investigated the effect of complex 3 on cell migration and invasion using transwell migration and wound-healing assays. As shown in Figure 5B, in the absence of complex 3, cells migrate rapidly, and the gap is significantly reduced. In contrast, fewer migratory cells and narrower migration distances are observed with the addition of complex 3. The transwell invasion results in Figure 5B match those in Figure 5C. Furthermore, we investigated the expressions of extracellular matrix proteins, MMP-2 and MMP-9, which play an essential role in the degradation of the basal lamina and the extracellular matrix, and can promote tumor cell metastasis.(65,66) As exhibited in Figure 5D, complex 3 could effectively inhibit the expression of MMP-2 and MMP-9. These data show that complex 3 inhibited the migration and invasion abilities of ASPC-1 cells.
    Also, using a dual propidium iodide (PI)/Annexin-V staining flow cytometry assay, we explored the occurrence of apoptosis in ASPC-1 cells treated for 24 h with complex 3. It was observed in Figure 6A that complex 3 significantly induced ASPC-1 cells apoptosis dose-dependently. Based on the evidence of the localization of complex 3 in the mitochondria in ASPC-1 cells, we envisaged that the complex would likely involve the mitochondrial-mediated apoptotic pathway. Thus, the mitochondrial membrane potential of ASPC-1 cells was evaluated by flow cytometry using the JC-1 probe. JC-1 exists in its aggregates form with red fluorescence in healthy cells, whereas it forms “J-monomeric,” showing green fluorescence in necrotic/apoptotic cells. From Figure 6B, treating ASPC-1 cells with complex 3 caused mitochondrial membrane potential (green fluorescence increase) loss dose-dependently. Mitochondrial apoptosis releases cytochrome c from the mitochondrial intermembrane space into the cytoplasm.(67) Therefore, the changes of cytochrome c in mitochondria were further examined. As presented in Figure 6C, complex 3 could lead to a dose-dependent decrease in the amount of cytochrome c in the mitochondria, confirming that treatment with complex 3 resulted in the mitochondrial release of cytochrome c. Subsequently, the activation of caspase-9 was initiated by the cytoplasmic cytochrome c and executed the apoptosis program (Figure 6D). These results indicated that complex 3 evoked the mitochondrial-mediated apoptotic pathway.
    The cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction signaling pathway is involved in the proliferation, differentiation, and immunity of cells.(68) Dysfunction of cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction can cause cell death. KEGG analysis revealed that tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member 12A, pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-18, and growth/differentiation factor 15 are upregulated, and TGFB3 is downregulated in this pathway.
    Collectively, the results demonstrate that complex 3 performs its anticancer functions by altering multiple pathways (Figure S6), such as, ferroptosis, MAPK signaling, and cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction signaling.

    Tumor Spheroid Assay and Xenograft Studies

    Compared with monolayer tumor cells, multicell tumor spheroids adequately reflect several solid tumor characteristics, such as, the secretion of soluble mediators, specific hypoxic zones, proliferation gradients, and spatial architectures.(69) In simulating the three-dimensional (3D) structure of malignant tissues and internal tumor microenvironments, multicellular tumor spheroids are significantly better than monolayer tumor cells. Therefore, recently, tumor spheroid systems have become widely used as models for simulating tumor tissues in vivo.(70) Here, ASPC-1 tumor spheroids were successfully cultured and used to evaluate the potential antisolid-tumor activity of complex 3. Figure 7 displays the inhibitory effects on the 3D ASPC-1 tumor spheroids following treatment with different concentrations of complex 3. The tumor spheroids increase in size and are very compact in the control group. Conversely, as evaluated by cell membrane rupture, the tumor spheroids, surface disintegration, cell leakage, and loss of 3D structure are observed in the complex 3-treated group at 0.4 μM and especially at 0.8 μM.
    To further evaluate the in vivo therapeutic efficacy of complex 3, an ASPC-1 tumor-bearing mice model was created. The tumor volume and body weight of the mice were monitored every 3 days for 21 days. At the end of the experiments, as shown in Figure 8A, the tumor volumes in mice treated with complex 3 at 1.5 and 3 mg/kg were much smaller than the tumor volumes in mice treated with normal saline (vehicle control). Compared with the control group, the tumor volume after 21 days of treatment was 61.9 ± 6.73% for 1.5 mg/kg and 45.4 ± 4.28% for 3 mg/kg. Importantly, no significant weight loss (Figure 8B) or mortality was observed for complex 3-treated mice during the post-treatment period.
    Furthermore, the distribution of complex 3 in major organs of tumor-bearing mice was examined. As shown in Figure 8C, an ex vivo fluorescence imaging study showed strong signals in the tumor, kidney, and liver, indicating that complex 3 can effectively reach the tumor tissue, reduce side effects, and was mainly excreted through the liver and kidney system. Also, a weak fluorescent signal is observed in the brain, and complex 3 can cross the in vitro blood–brain barrier model at a ratio of about 17% (Figure S7), suggesting that complex 3 was able to cross the blood–brain barrier.
    Next, the hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) analysis of kidney, tumor, and liver was further adopted to assess in vivo safety and antitumor efficacy after treatment with complex 3. There were no major histopathological changes in the liver and kidney sections (Figure 8D), further confirming the in vivo tolerability of complex 3. In contrast, obvious differences in the tumor tissue morphology were observed between the groups treated and the control group. Compared with the control, tumor cellularity was decreased, and nuclear shrinkage and fragmentation were observed in the complex 3-treated groups (Figure 8D). Likewise, TUNEL staining of tumor tissue sections showed that complex 3 produced obvious cell apoptosis, while there were almost no apoptotic cells observed in the control group (Figure 8E). These data clearly suggested that complex 3 possessed potent antitumor activity against the growth of inoculated ASPC-1 tumors in mice with low toxicity.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Here, three new fluorescent dithiocarbazate–copper complexes with different coordination geometries were prepared based on anion adjustment, and their in vitro anticancer and imaging properties were investigated. The mixed-valent copper(I/II) complex 3 has good antipancreatic cancer ability in vitro and in vivo and can be used for bioimaging beyond living cells or in vitro. Further anticancer-mechanism studies demonstrated that complex 3 kills pancreatic cancer cells through multiple pathways, including ferroptosis, MAPK, and cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction pathways. Given the acquired or inherent resistance of pancreatic tumors or both to apoptosis-inducing chemical anticancer agents, compounds, such as, complex 3, capable of killing pancreatic cancer cells through ferroptosis, are attractive preclinical candidates for treating chemoresistant malignant tumors.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Materials

    MTT, methyl hydrazinecarbodithioate, di(pyridin-2-yl)methanone, and CuCl2·2H2O/Cu(NO3)2·3H2O/CuBr2 were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. All other solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial sources. C, H, and N elemental analyses were acquired using a LECO CHNS-932 analyzer. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum (KBr pellets) was recorded in the region of 400–4000 cm–1 on an InterSpec 2020 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded by a LS 45 PerkinElmer spectrofluorometer. Magnetic susceptibility data were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS3 SQUID. Atomic absorption spectroscopy measurements were taken on a AAnalyst 600 spectrometer (PerkinElmer). The relative purity of the HL ligand and its copper complexes used in this study was >95%, as examined by elemental analysis.

    Synthesis of the Ligand and Complexes 1–3

    The HL ligand was synthesized according to the literature procedure.(41) Briefly, the HL ligand was prepared by refluxing methyl hydrazinecarbodithioate (0.61 g, 5 mmol) and di(pyridin-2-yl)methanone (0.92 g, 5 mmol) for a period of 1 h in MeOH to obtain a yellow solution. Yellow shiny crystals of HL were generated through slow evaporation of the solvent at 4 °C, yield 1.09 g (76%). Calcd for C13H12N4S2 (288.39): C, 54.14; H, 4.19; N, 19.43. Found: C, 54.08; H, 4.23; N, 19.37. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 14.95 (s, 1H), 8.86 (ddd, J = 4.8, 1.6, 1.0 Hz, 1H), 8.63 (ddd, J = 4.8, 1.6, 1.0 Hz, 1H), 8.13–7.86 (m, 3H), 7.67–7.58 (m, 2H), 7.54 (ddd, J = 7.2, 4.8, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 2.59 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 201.4, 155.1, 150.9, 149.1, 148.8, 144.6, 138.2, 137.9, 128.0, 125.7, 124.8, 124.0, 17.4 ppm (Figures S8 and S9).
    The complexes, [CuII(L)(Cl)] (1), [CuII2(L)2(NO3)2] (2) and [CuII2CuI(L)2(Br)3] (3), were synthesized as described below. One mole equivalent of the HL ligand was added to ethanolic (40 mL) solution of either CuCl2·2H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, or CuBr2 and refluxed for 0.5 h. The mixing solution was then allowed to cool to room temperature and filtered. Dark-green block crystals of these copper complexes were obtained through slow evaporation of the filtrate solvent.

    [CuII(L)(Cl)] (1)

    Yield: 61%. Anal. Calcd for C13H11ClCuN4S2 (386.37): C, 40.41; H, 2.87; N, 14.50. Found: C, 40.62; H, 2.93; N, 14.69. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3063m, 1591m, 1550m, 1491m, 1470m, 1414vs, 1328s, 1302s, 1260m, 1187m, 1159w, 1087vs, 996vs, 954m, 742m, 698s, 653m, 597w, 523w, 421w.

    [CuII(L)(NO3)]2 (2)

    Yield: 72%. Anal. Calcd for C26H22Cu2N10O6S4 (825.86): C, 37.81; H, 2.68; N, 16.96. Found: C, 37.64; H, 2.53; N, 16.73. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3076m, 2360m, 1596m, 1471vs, 1380vs, 1283vs, 1157m, 1095s, 1009vs, 956m, 812w, 789m, 768w, 747m, 661w, 624w, 607w.

    [CuII2CuI(L)2(Br)3] (3)

    Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd for C26H22Br3Cu3N8S4 (1005.11): C, 31.07; H, 2.21; N, 11.15. Found: C, 31.21; H, 2.33; N, 11.07. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2361w, 1588m, 1543w, 1403vs, 1331s, 1306m, 1208m, 1087s, 994s, 911m, 793m, 747w, 651w, 604w, 523w.

    Cu Complex Crystal Structure Determination

    The X-ray crystallography data of complexes 1–3 were obtained on a Bruker SMART APEX2 with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069) radiation at room temperature. The experimental structures of these copper complexes were obtained using the Olex-2 program.(71) Non-H atoms are refined anisotropic thermal parameters. Cambridge Crystal Data Center deposition numbers: 1964509 for 1, 1964510 for 2, and 1964511 for 3. The selected crystallographic data for complexes 1–3 are reported in Tables S1 and S2.

    Cell Cytotoxicity Assays

    Human pancreatic cancer cells (BxPc-3, ASPC-1, and PANC-1) and human normal lung fibroblast cells (WI-38) were maintained in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium or RPMI-1640 culture containing 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% streptomycin/penicillin at 37 °C and 5% CO2.
    The cytotoxicity of the copper complexes was investigated by MTT assay. In brief, the noncancer cells and cancer cells were seeded into 96-well plates at 5 × 104 cells/mL and then incubated at 37 °C and 5% CO2. After 24 h incubation, the cells were incubated with different concentrations (0–100 μM) of test compounds for 48 h. Then, 10 μL of MTT saline solution (5 mg/mL) was added to each well, and the plate was then incubated for 4 h at 37 °C and 5% CO2. The supernatant in each well of the 96-well plates was replaced by 100 μL of DMSO to dissolve the MTT-formazan. The absorbance was then read at 570 nm using an infinite M200 Pro microplate reader.

    Cellular and in Vivo Imaging Assay

    On the basis of the fluorescence properties of complex 3, fluorescence cellular imaging using complex 3 was performed with a Zeiss LSM 510 confocal microscope using oil objective (63×). Briefly, ASPC-1 cells were treated with different DRAQ5 (nuclear localization), Golgi-Tracker Red (golgi localization), ER-Tracker Red (endoplasmic reticulum localization), LysoTracker Red (lysosomal localization), and MitoTracker Deep Red FM (mitochondrial localization) dyes under 37 °C and 5% CO2 conditions followed by incubation with the copper complex 3 (10 μM) at 37 °C and 5% CO2. Complex 3, DRAQ5, Golgi-Tracker Red, ER-Tracker Red, LysoTracker Red, and MitoTracker Deep Red FM were excited independently at 405, 638, 589, 587, 577, and 638 nm and their emissions detected at 524, 690, 617, 615, 590, and 665 nm, respectively.
    In vivo imaging was carried out in male BALB/c mice (Hunan SJA Laboratory Animal Co., Ltd.) and an in vivo imaging system (UVP iBox, Scientia). All mouse experiments conformed to the Guidelines for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals published by Guilin Medical University. The mouse was anesthetized with 7% chloral hydrate for imaging. After that, the saline solution of complex 3 (200 μL, 3 mg/kg) was injected into the mouse by intraperitoneal injection. Images were taken under conditions as follows: excitation filter 455–495 nm, emission filter 535/50 nm, and exposure time 2 s. The mouse was imaged again at 0 min, 30 min, 2 h, and 4 h for comparison. In addition, based on complex 3’s fluorescence, the blood circulation half-life of complex 3 was calculated according to the method in the literature.(72)

    Proteomics Analysis

    Protein Extraction and TMT Labeling

    In order to establish a proteomics model for studying the anticancer mechanism of complex 3, ASPC-1 cells were treated with complex 3 (0.4 μM) or vehicle control for 24 h. After incubation, cells were harvested and washed with cold phosphate buffered saline (PBS) twice. Then, the ASPC-1 cell samples were homogenized with SDT [4% sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), 100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.6] lysate buffer, followed by heating in a boiling H2O bath for 15 min. The mixture was centrifuged at 14,000g and 4 °C for 15 min to remove cell debris. The protein concentrations of the supernatants were quantified using the bicinchoninic acid (BCA) assay. The proteins (20 μg of protein for each sample) were separated on 12% SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis gel (constant voltage 250 V, 40 min). Next, filter-aided sample preparation digestion was performed for protein digestion. In brief, 200 μg of each protein was deterged, alkylated, incubated, and digested. Finally, the resulting peptides were collected and processed with a TMT kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol.

    High-pH Reverse Phase Fractionation and LC–MS/MS Analysis

    High-pH reverse phase fractionation chromatography was carried out using an Agilent 1260 infinity II high-performance liquid chromatography system. Briefly, the samples first were incubated with buffer A (10 mM HCOONH4, 5% acetonitrile, pH 10.0). Subsequently, the mixtures were loaded onto a C18 column (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with buffer A and buffer B (10 mM HCOONH4, 85% acetonitrile, pH 10.0). During elution, the UV absorbance at 214 nm of the eluent was monitored. Forty fractions were collected every min and dried by vacuum centrifugation for liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry (LC–MS/MS) analysis.
    Nanoflow LC–MS/MS analysis of peptide samples was conducted on a Q Exactive mass spectrometer coupled to an Easy-nLC. Each fraction was dissolved in 0.1% formic acid. The peptide mixture was then separated on a reversed-phase C18 column at a flow rate of 300 nL/min. The chromatographic elution program was 6% solvent B (0.1% formic acid in 98% acetonitrile) for 3 min, then 6–28% over 42 min and returning to 38% solvent B over 5 min, and then maintaining 100% solvent B for the last 5 min. The separated peptides were directly conducted by Q Exactive plus on-line. The data-dependent top 10 method was chosen for MS data acquisition. The survey scans (350 to 1800 m/z) were acquired at a resolution of 70,000. The automatic gain control was set at 3 × 106. The tryptic peptide ions (precursor ions) were selected for high-energy collision dissociation at a normalization collision-energy value of 30 to obtain MS/MS spectra. The fragment ions (product ions) were acquired at a resolution of 35,000.

    Proteomic Data Analysis and Bioinformatics Analysis

    The raw MS/MS data were input into Proteome Discoverer software (version 2.1) for data processing. Peptides were identified and quantified using Mascot 2.6 software and the Uniprot_HomoSapiens database (20386_20180905). The identification and quantitative analysis parameters were set as follows: enzyme (trypsin), max missed cleavages (2), instrument (ESI-TRAP), precursor mass tolerance (±10 ppm), fragment mass tolerance (0.05 Da), use average precursor mass (false), modification groups from quan method (TMT 10plex), dynamic modifications (oxidation and acetyl), static modifications (carbamidomethyl), and database pattern (decoy). For protein identification, the peptide false discovery rate was adjusted to ≤0.01.
    GO annotation of differentially expressed proteins was derived from the Blast2GO database (www.geneontology.org). Differentially expressed proteins were classified by GO annotation based on three categories, including molecular functions, cellular compartments, and biological processes. KEGG pathway analysis of differentially expressed proteins was performed with KEGG Orthology and Links Annotation software and the online KEGG analysis database (www.genome.jp/kegg/pathway.html). KEGG pathway enrichment and GO enrichment analyses were performed on the basis of the Fisher’s exact test.

    Lipid ROS Production Measurement

    Cellular lipid ROS generation in the ASPC-1 cells was measured by BODIPY-C11 lipid probes (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Briefly, ASPC-1 cells were exposed to complex 3 at the indicated concentrations. After 24 h, cells were washed and labeled with BODIPY-C11 (5 μM) for 15 min at 37 °C. Lipid ROS were determined on a flow cytometer (FACScan, Becton Dickinson) using channels for reduced dye and oxidized dyes simultaneously.

    Antimetastatic Assay

    The antimetastatic studies for copper complex 3 were conducted in ASPC-1 cells by the scratching wound healing assay and invasion assay. For the scratching wound healing assay, the ASPC-1 cells were seeded in a six-well plate and then cultured until they reached ∼90% confluence. Wounds gaps in the monolayer cells were generated using a sterile pipette tip. Then, the cellular debris were carefully removed with cold PBS and cultured in RPMI-1640 medium containing 1% fetal bovine serum (to minimize ASPC-1 cell proliferation during the assay) with or without complex 3 for 24 h.
    The invasion assay was performed with ASPC-1 cells using Matrigel-coated 24-well transwells, which allow cells to migrate through a polycarbonate filter membrane (8.0 μm pores). In brief, 75 μL of a Matrigel working solution (1 mg/mL) was added to the upper surface and allowed to solidify at 37 °C for 1 h. Then, 750 μL of RPMI-1640 medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum were added to the lower well, and 100 μL of cell suspension at a density of 5 × 104 cells/well with or without complex 3 was plated in the upper chamber. After 24 h of incubation, the adherent cells on the undersurface of the insert were fixed in MeOH and stained with 0.1% crystal violet dye.

    Cell Apoptosis

    Apoptosis analysis was carried out in ASPC-1 cancer cells and analyzed by the Annexin V fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) kit (Beyotime, Nanjing, China) and flow cytometry. In brief, the ASPC-1 cells (at a density 5 × 104 cells/well) were seeded in six-well plates and cultured for 24 h. After that, the cells were treated with the vehicle control or complex 3 (0.4 and 0.8 μM). After 24 h, the cells were harvested and stained with Annexin V-FITC/PI according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Cell apoptosis was immediately observed by flow cytometry.

    Mitochondrial Membrane Potential

    The changes of mitochondrial membrane potential were analyzed by the JC-1 kit (Beyotime, Nanjing, China) and flow cytometry. In brief, cells were harvested and washed twice with cold-PBS, followed by resuspension in 5 mg/mL JC-1 solution and incubation at 37 °C for 0.5 h. After that, the cells were rinsed and suspended in PBS, and the JC-1 fluorescence was immediately observed by flow cytometry.

    Western Blotting

    Western blotting analysis was carried out as previously described.(42) Proteins extracted from mitochondria or whole cells. The corresponding protein concentration was quantified by the BCA kit (Beyotime, Nanjing, China). Target proteins, including anti-β-actin (Abcam), anti-HMOX1 (Abcam), anti-ACSL4 (Abcam), anti-TGFB3 (Proteintech), anti-caspase-9 (Abcam), anti-c-Fos (Abcam), anti-phos-ERK1/2 (Abcam), anti-MMP-2 (Abcam), anti-MMP-9 (Abcam), and anti-cytochrome c (Abcam), were incubated with the corresponding primary antibodies and subsequently monitored using secondary antibodies conjugated to alkaline phosphatase.

    Blood–Brain Barrier Model in Vitro

    The blood–brain barrier model in vitro was established according to literature procedures.(73) Briefly, the human brain microvascular endothelial cells were seeded on the transwell upper side, and the ASPC-1 cells were cultured in the basolateral compartment of the transwell. After incubation for several days, when the resistance of the human brain microvascular endothelial cells on the upper side exceeded 250 Ω cm2, complex 3 (0.4 μM) was added to the upper side and incubated at 37 °C for 48 h. Then, the transportation ratio of complex 3 was measured by atomic absorption to determine the content of copper in the upper and lower chambers.

    Tumor Spheroid Assay and Xenograft Studies

    The inhibition of 3D tumor spheroid growths was evaluated by measuring the size of tumor spheroids following treatment with different concentrations of complex 3. In brief, ASPC-1 cells were grown to ∼600 cells/well using an ultralow attachment and a round-bottom 96-well plate (Corning, Sigma-Aldrich). After 2 days of incubation, the selected spheroids were treated with 0.1% DMSO (control) or different concentrations of complex 3 for 7 days.
    In vivo anticancer activity of complex 3 was assessed through the pancreatic cancer xenograft model. All mouse experiments conformed to the Guidelines for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals published by Guilin Medical University. ASPC-1 cancer cells (4.0 × 106) in a 200 μL suspension of serum-free medium were injected subcutaneously into the right flank of six-week male BALB/c mice (Hunan SJA Laboratory Animal Co., Ltd.). Body weight and tumor volume of the mice were monitored every 3 days. The tumor size (V) was calculated through caliper measurement as follows: V = (tumor length) × (tumor width)2/2. Tumor-bearing mice were randomly divided into two groups (n = 8/group) when the average tumor size reached 100 mm3. Mice in different treatment groups were intraperitoneally injected with normal saline and complex 3 (1.5 and 3 mg/kg) once every 3 days. The study was concluded on day 21 when the average tumor volume in the group reached 1000 mm3. In addition, organs (tumor, heart, spleen, lung, kidney, liver, and brain) were harvested and imaged after 2 h postinjection to investigate the distribution of complex 3. At the time of necropsy, kidneys, livers, and tumors were collected and sectioned. Sections were then stained with H&E to facilitate histologic examination. In addition, the apoptotic level of tumor sections was assessed using the One Step TUNEL Apoptosis Assay Kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Beyotime, Nanjing, China).

    Statistical Analysis

    All values were analyzed using SPSS software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) and are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Statistical analysis comparisons between different groups were carried out using Student’s t-test. p < 0.05 was considered significant.

    1. 1
      Rahib, L.; Smith, B. D.; Aizenberg, R.; Rosenzweig, A. B.; Fleshman, J. M.; Matrisian, L. M. Projecting cancer incidence and deaths to 2030: the unexpected burden of thyroid, liver, and pancreas cancers in the United States. Cancer Res. 2014, 74, 2913– 2921,  DOI: 10.1158/0008-5472.can-14-0155
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Projecting Cancer Incidence and Deaths to 2030: The Unexpected Burden of Thyroid, Liver, and Pancreas Cancers in the United States
      Rahib, Lola; Smith, Benjamin D.; Aizenberg, Rhonda; Rosenzweig, Allison B.; Fleshman, Julie M.; Matrisian, Lynn M.
      Cancer Research (2014), 74 (11), 2913-2921CODEN: CNREA8; ISSN:0008-5472. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      Cancer incidence and deaths in the United States were projected for the most common cancer types for the years 2020 and 2030 based on changing demographics and the av. annual percentage changes in incidence and death rates. Breast, prostate, and lung cancers will remain the top cancer diagnoses throughout this time, but thyroid cancer will replace colorectal cancer as the fourth leading cancer diagnosis by 2030, and melanoma and uterine cancer will become the fifth and sixth most common cancers, resp. Lung cancer is projected to remain the top cancer killer throughout this time period. However, pancreas and liver cancers are projected to surpass breast, prostate, and colorectal cancers to become the second and third leading causes of cancer-related death by 2030, resp. Advances in screening, prevention, and treatment can change cancer incidence and/or death rates, but it will require a concerted effort by the research and healthcare communities now to effect a substantial change for the future. Cancer Res; 74(11); 2913-21. ©2014 AACR.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXovFalur0%253D&md5=893d688f1ccba88ee094b743f7e4f152
    2. 2
      Vincent, A.; Herman, J.; Schulick, R.; Hruban, R. H.; Goggins, M. Pancreatic cancer. Lancet 2011, 378, 607– 620,  DOI: 10.1016/s0140-6736(10)62307-0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Pancreatic cancer
      Vincent Audrey; Herman Joseph; Schulick Rich; Hruban Ralph H; Goggins Michael
      Lancet (London, England) (2011), 378 (9791), 607-20 ISSN:.
      Substantial progress has been made in our understanding of the biology of pancreatic cancer, and advances in patients' management have also taken place. Evidence is beginning to show that screening first-degree relatives of individuals with several family members affected by pancreatic cancer can identify non-invasive precursors of this malignant disease. The incidence of and number of deaths caused by pancreatic tumours have been gradually rising, even as incidence and mortality of other common cancers have been declining. Despite developments in detection and management of pancreatic cancer, only about 4% of patients will live 5 years after diagnosis. Survival is better for those with malignant disease localised to the pancreas, because surgical resection at present offers the only chance of cure. Unfortunately, 80-85% of patients present with advanced unresectable disease. Furthermore, pancreatic cancer responds poorly to most chemotherapeutic agents. Hence, we need to understand the biological mechanisms that contribute to development and progression of pancreatic tumours. In this Seminar we will discuss the most common and deadly form of pancreatic cancer, pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3MjlvFOmsg%253D%253D&md5=fb7f79c8c02f2f2bad5e5ad7a9b09096
    3. 3
      Siegel, R. L.; Miller, K. D.; Jemal, A. Cancer statistics, 2016. Ca-Cancer J. Clin. 2016, 66, 7– 30,  DOI: 10.3322/caac.21332
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Cancer statistics, 2016
      Siegel Rebecca L; Miller Kimberly D; Jemal Ahmedin
      CA: a cancer journal for clinicians (2016), 66 (1), 7-30 ISSN:.
      Each year, the American Cancer Society estimates the numbers of new cancer cases and deaths that will occur in the United States in the current year and compiles the most recent data on cancer incidence, mortality, and survival. Incidence data were collected by the National Cancer Institute (Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results [SEER] Program), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (National Program of Cancer Registries), and the North American Association of Central Cancer Registries. Mortality data were collected by the National Center for Health Statistics. In 2016, 1,685,210 new cancer cases and 595,690 cancer deaths are projected to occur in the United States. Overall cancer incidence trends (13 oldest SEER registries) are stable in women, but declining by 3.1% per year in men (from 2009-2012), much of which is because of recent rapid declines in prostate cancer diagnoses. The cancer death rate has dropped by 23% since 1991, translating to more than 1.7 million deaths averted through 2012. Despite this progress, death rates are increasing for cancers of the liver, pancreas, and uterine corpus, and cancer is now the leading cause of death in 21 states, primarily due to exceptionally large reductions in death from heart disease. Among children and adolescents (aged birth-19 years), brain cancer has surpassed leukemia as the leading cause of cancer death because of the dramatic therapeutic advances against leukemia. Accelerating progress against cancer requires both increased national investment in cancer research and the application of existing cancer control knowledge across all segments of the population.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC28rot1Kjug%253D%253D&md5=2d4030a531945c5ebaaab181bfd80457
    4. 4
      Cleary, S. P.; Gryfe, R.; Guindi, M.; Greig, P.; Smith, L.; Mackenzie, R.; Strasberg, S.; Hanna, S.; Taylor, B.; Langer, B.; Gallinger, S. Prognostic factors in resected pancreatic adenocarcinoma: analysis of actual 5-year survivors. J. Am. Coll. Surg. 2004, 198, 722– 731,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jamcollsurg.2004.01.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Prognostic factors in resected pancreatic adenocarcinoma: analysis of actual 5-year survivors
      Cleary Sean P; Gryfe Robert; Guindi Maha; Greig Paul; Smith Lloyd; Mackenzie Robert; Strasberg Steven; Hanna Sherif; Taylor Bryce; Langer Bernard; Gallinger Steven
      Journal of the American College of Surgeons (2004), 198 (5), 722-31 ISSN:1072-7515.
      BACKGROUND: Pancreatic cancer is a rapidly fatal disease with very few 5-year survivors even after aggressive surgical treatment. Our objective was to determine the actual 5-year survival rate of patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma who underwent a resection with curative intent in 5 teaching hospitals within the University of Toronto system. We then sought to determine clinical and histopathologic features of 5-year survivors to determine factors associated with a favorable prognosis. STUDY DESIGN: A retrospective chart review was performed using surgeon and hospital databases to identify patients who had a surgical resection for pancreatic adenocarcinoma between January 1, 1988, and December 31, 1996. RESULTS: One hundred twenty-three patients who had a resection and a pathologic diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma with complete followup were identified from seven surgical practices. Mean survival (+/- standard error) in this series was 31.7 +/- 3.5 months (median 13.6 months). There were 18 5-year survivors (14.6%), including 5 patients (4.1%) who survived longer than 10 years. The survivors included 13 patients who had undergone a Whipple resection, 4 who had undergone a distal pancreatectomy, and 1 who had undergone a total pancreatectomy. Tumor size, lack of jaundice at presentation, negative nodal disease, low tumor grade, and a low tumor stage were all significant predictors of survival in univariate analysis (all p < 0.05). Only tumor stage (hazard ratio [95% confidence interval]: stage IIA 1.5 [0.8 to 2.8], stage IIB 2.6 [1.4 to 4.7], stage III 1.8 [0.8 to 4.3]) and tumor grade (hazard ratio [95% confidence interval]: moderately differentiated 1.6 [0.9 to 2.9], and poorly differentiated 3.1 [1.6 to 6.2]) were independently associated with survival differences in a multivariate Cox proportional hazards model. CONCLUSIONS: We conclude that longterm survival from pancreatic adenocarcinoma is possible if the disease is identified in its early stages. These and other similar data should provide further stimulus for the development and evaluation of novel screening strategies to improve early detection of this disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2c3htlWksQ%253D%253D&md5=e9cc57f6bc22c656ed5e30112fbe1740
    5. 5
      Kuang, Y.; Sechi, M.; Nurra, S.; Ljungman, M.; Neamati, N. Design and synthesis of novel reactive oxygen species inducers for the treatment of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 1576– 1594,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.7b01463
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Design and Synthesis of Novel Reactive Oxygen Species Inducers for the Treatment of Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma
      Kuang, Yuting; Sechi, Mario; Nurra, Salvatore; Ljungman, Mats; Neamati, Nouri
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (4), 1576-1594CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Quinazolinediones such as I were prepd. as inducers of reactive oxygen species (ROS) for potential use as antitumor agents for the treatment of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC); the inhibition of human PDAC cells was detd. for all of the compds. and the toxicities of selected compds. to normal pancreatic cells, and the effects on various cellular systems was detd. for selected compds. I was the most potent redox modulator candidate of the tested compds., inducing substantial ROS prodn. in PDAC cells. Nascent RNA sequencing following treatments with quinazolinediones revealed induction of stress responses in nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, and mitochondria of pancreatic cancer cells; the quinazolinedione also induced Nrf2-mediated oxidative stress and unfolded protein responses as demonstrated by dose-dependent increases in RNA synthesis of representative genes such as NQO1, HMOX1, DDIT3, and HSPA5. At 5.0 μM, I blocked mitochondrial function by inhibiting mtDNA transcription and downregulating the mtDNA-encoded OXPHOS enzymes. Treatment with I was well tolerated in vivo and significantly delayed tumor growth in mice; I was also tested in combination with the current pancreatic cancer agent gemcitabine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXotVyqtA%253D%253D&md5=ec0cb6c8914a7841c7ff8906cf53ef49
    6. 6
      Ryan, D. P.; Hong, T. S.; Bardeesy, N. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma. N. Engl. J. Med. 2014, 371, 1039– 1049,  DOI: 10.1056/nejmra1404198
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Ryan, David P.; Hong, Theodore S.; Bardeesy, Nabeel
      New England Journal of Medicine (2014), 371 (11), 1039-1049, 11 pp.CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:1533-4406. (Massachusetts Medical Society)

    7. 7
      Von Hoff, D. D.; Ervin, T.; Arena, F. P.; Chiorean, E. G.; Infante, J.; Moore, M.; Seay, T.; Tjulandin, S. A.; Ma, W. W.; Saleh, M. N.; Harris, M.; Reni, M.; Dowden, S.; Laheru, D.; Bahary, N.; Ramanathan, R. K.; Tabernero, J.; Hidalgo, M.; Goldstein, D.; Van Cutsem, E.; Wei, X.; Iglesias, J.; Renschler, M. F. Increased survival in pancreatic cancer with nab-paclitaxel plus gemcitabine. N. Engl. J. Med. 2013, 369, 1691– 1703,  DOI: 10.1056/nejmoa1304369
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Increased survival in pancreatic cancer with nab-paclitaxel plus gemcitabine
      Von Hoff, Daniel D.; Ervin, Thomas; Arena, Francis P.; Chiorean, E. Gabriela; Infante, Jeffrey; Moore, Malcolm; Seay, Thomas; Tjulandin, Sergei A.; Ma, Wen Wee; Saleh, Mansoor N.; Harris, Marion; Reni, Michele; Dowden, Scot; Laheru, Daniel; Bahary, Nathan; Ramanathan, Ramesh K.; Tabernero, Josep; Hidalgo, Manuel; Goldstein, David; Van Cutsem, Eric; Wei, Xinyu; Iglesias, Jose; Renschler, Markus F.
      New England Journal of Medicine (2013), 369 (18), 1691-1703CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:0028-4793. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      BACKGROUND: In a phase 1-2 trial of albumin-bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel) plus gemcitabine, substantial clin. activity was noted in patients with advanced pancreatic cancer. We conducted a phase 3 study of the efficacy and safety of the combination vs. gemcitabine monotherapy in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. METHODS: We randomly assigned patients with a Karnofsky performance-status score of 70 or more (on a scale from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating better performance status) to nab-paclitaxel (125 mg per square meter of body-surface area) followed by gemcitabine (1000 mg per square meter) on days 1, 8, and 15 every 4 wk or gemcitabine monotherapy (1000 mg per square meter) weekly for 7 of 8 wk (cycle 1) and then on days 1, 8, and 15 every 4 wk (cycle 2 and subsequent cycles). Patients received the study treatment until disease progression. The primary end point was overall survival; secondary end points were progression-free survival and overall response rate. RESULTS: A total of 861 patients were randomly assigned to nab-paclitaxel plus gemcitabine (431 patients) or gemcitabine (430). The median overall survival was 8.5 mo in the nab-paclitaxel-gemcitabine group as compared with 6.7 mo in the gemcitabine group (hazard ratio for death, 0.72; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.62 to 0.83; P<0.001). The survival rate was 35% in the nab-paclitaxel-gemcitabine group vs. 22% in the gemcitabine group at 1 yr, and 9% vs. 4% at 2 years. The median progression-free survival was 5.5 mo in the nab-paclitaxel-gemcitabine group, as compared with 3.7 mo in the gemcitabine group (hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.58 to 0.82; P<0.001); the response rate according to independent review was 23% vs. 7% in the two groups (P<0.001). The most common adverse events of grade 3 or higher were neutropenia (38% in the nab-paclitaxel-gemcitabine group vs. 27% in the gemcitabine group), fatigue (17% vs. 7%), and neuropathy (17% vs. 1%). Febrile neutropenia occurred in 3% vs. 1% of the patients in the two groups. In the nab-paclitaxel-gemcitabine group, neuropathy of grade 3 or higher improved to grade 1 or lower in a median of 29 days. CONCLUSIONS: In patients with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma, nab-paclitaxel plus gemcitabine significantly improved overall survival, progression-free survival, and response rate, but rates of peripheral neuropathy and myelosuppression were increased.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslCjsb7I&md5=b1169c7e9879c08061dd9e9389dc36fe
    8. 8
      Conroy, T.; Desseigne, F.; Ychou, M.; Bouché, O.; Guimbaud, R.; Bécouarn, Y.; Adenis, A.; Raoul, J.-L.; Gourgou-Bourgade, S.; de la Fouchardière, C.; Bennouna, J.; Bachet, J.-B.; Khemissa-Akouz, F.; Péré-Vergé, D.; Delbaldo, C.; Assenat, E.; Chauffert, B.; Michel, P.; Montoto-Grillot, C.; Ducreux, M. FOLFIRINOX versus gemcitabine for metastatic pancreatic cancer. N. Engl. J. Med. 2011, 364, 1817– 1825,  DOI: 10.1056/nejmoa1011923
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      FOLFIRINOX versus gemcitabine or metastatic pancreatic cancer
      Conroy, Thierry; Desseigne, Francoise; Ychou, Marc; Bouche, Olivier; Guimbaud, Rosine; Becouarn, Yves; Adenis, Antoine; Raoul, Jean-Luc; Gourgou-Bourgade, Sophie; de la Fouchardiere, Christelle; Bennouna, Jaafar; Bachet, Jean-Baptiste; Khemissa-Akouz, Faiza; Pere-Verge, Denis; Delbaldo, Catherine; Assenat, Eric; Chauffert, Bruno; Michel, Pierre; Montoto-Grillot, Christine; Ducreux, Michel
      New England Journal of Medicine (2011), 364 (19), 1817-1825CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:0028-4793. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      BACKGROUND Data are lacking on the efficacy and safety of a combination chemotherapy regimen consisting of oxaliplatin, irinotecan, fluorouracil, and leucovorin (FOLFIRINOX) as compared with gemcitabine as first-line therapy in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. METHODS We randomly assigned 342 patients with an Eastern Cooperative Oncol. Group performance status score of 0 or 1 (on a scale of 0 to 5, with higher scores indicating a greater severity of illness) to receive FOLFIRINOX (oxaliplatin, 85 mg per square meter of body-surface area; irinotecan, 180 mg per square meter; leucovorin, 400 mg per square meter; and fluorouracil, 400 mg per square meter given as a bolus followed by 2400 mg per square meter given as a 46-h continuous infusion, every 2 wk) or gemcitabine at a dose of 1000 mg per square meter weekly for 7 of 8 wk and then weekly for 3 of 4 wk. Six months of chemotherapy were recommended in both groups in patients who had a response. The primary end point was overall survival. RESULTS The median overall survival was 11.1 mo in the FOLFIRINOX group as compared with 6.8 mo in the gemcitabine group (hazard ratio for death, 0.57; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.45 to 0.73; P < 0.001). Median progression-free survival was 6.4 mo in the FOLFIRINOX group and 3.3 mo in the gemcitabine group (hazard ratio for disease progression, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.37 to 0.59; P < 0.001). The objective response rate was 31.60% in the FOLFIRINOX group vs. 9.4% in the gemcitabine group (P < 0.001). More adverse events were noted in the FOLFIRINOX group; 5.4% of patients in this group had febrile neutropenia. At 6 mo, 31% of the patients in the FOLFIRINOX group had a definitive degrdn. of the quality of life vs. 66% in the gemcitabine group (hazard ratio, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.30 to 0.70; P < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS As compared with gemcitabine, FOLFIRINOX was assocd. with a survival advantage and had increased toxicity. FOLFIRINOX is an option for the treatment of patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer and good performance status.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXlvF2jsrw%253D&md5=a1a7135a6c97c4dc47233465ce0defd5
    9. 9
      Neoptolemos, J. P.; Kleeff, J.; Michl, P.; Costello, E.; Greenhalf, W.; Palmer, D. H. Therapeutic developments in pancreatic cancer: current and future perspectives. Nat. Rev. Gastroenterol. Hepatol. 2018, 15, 333– 348,  DOI: 10.1038/s41575-018-0005-x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Therapeutic developments in pancreatic cancer: current and future perspectives
      Neoptolemos John P; Kleeff Jorg; Kleeff Jorg; Costello Eithne; Greenhalf William; Palmer Daniel H; Michl Patrick
      Nature reviews. Gastroenterology & hepatology (2018), 15 (6), 333-348 ISSN:.
      The overall 5-year survival for pancreatic cancer has changed little over the past few decades, and pancreatic cancer is predicted to be the second leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the next decade in Western countries. The past few years, however, have seen improvements in first-line and second-line palliative therapies and considerable progress in increasing survival with adjuvant treatment. The use of biomarkers to help define treatment and the potential of neoadjuvant therapies also offer opportunities to improve outcomes. This Review brings together information on achievements to date, what is working currently and where successes are likely to be achieved in the future. Furthermore, we address the questions of how we should approach the development of pancreatic cancer treatments, including those for patients with metastatic, locally advanced and borderline resectable pancreatic cancer, as well as for patients with resected tumours. In addition to embracing newer strategies comprising genomics, stromal therapies and immunotherapies, conventional approaches using chemotherapy and radiotherapy still offer considerable prospects for greater traction and synergy with evolving concepts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MjovVOguw%253D%253D&md5=d1b4ab24b72f95c7077798a8258ccf58

      Barry, N. P. E.; Sadler, P. J. Exploration of the medical periodic table: towards new targets. Chem. Commun. 2013, 49, 5106– 5131,  DOI: 10.1039/c3cc41143e
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Exploration of the medical periodic table: towards new targets
      Barry, Nicolas P. E.; Sadler, Peter J.
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (45), 5106-5131CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metallodrugs offer potential for unique mechanisms of drug action based on the choice of the metal, its oxidn. state, the types and no. of coordinated ligands and the coordination geometry. We discuss recent progress in identifying new target sites and elucidating the mechanisms of action of anti-cancer, anti-bacterial, anti-viral, anti-parasitic, anti-inflammatory, and anti-neurodegenerative agents, as well as in the design of metal-based diagnostic agents. Progress in identifying and defining target sites has been accelerated recently by advances in proteomics, genomics and metal speciation anal. Examples of metal compds. and chelating agents (enzyme inhibitors) currently in clin. use, clin. trials or preclin. development are highlighted.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnsFaru7c%253D&md5=b91db5563e59a43e7f9d05860a03b3b0

      Tisato, F.; Marzano, C.; Porchia, M.; Pellei, M.; Santini, C. Copper in diseases and treatments, and copper-based anticancer strategies. Med. Res. Rev. 2010, 30, 708– 749,  DOI: 10.1002/med.20174
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Copper in diseases and treatments, and copper-based anticancer strategies
      Tisato, Francesco; Marzano, Cristina; Porchia, Marina; Pellei, Maura; Santini, Carlo
      Medicinal Research Reviews (2010), 30 (4), 708-749CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A review. Copper is found in all living organisms and is a crucial trace element in redox chem., growth and development. It is important for the function of several enzymes and proteins involved in energy metab., respiration, and DNA synthesis, notably cytochrome oxidase, superoxide dismutase, ascorbate oxidase, and tyrosinase. The major functions of copper-biol. mols. involve oxidn.-redn. reactions in which they react directly with mol. oxygen to produce free radicals. Therefore, copper requires tightly regulated homeostatic mechanisms to ensure adequate supplies without any toxic effects. Overload or deficiency of copper is assocd., resp., with Wilson disease (WD) and Menkes disease (MD), which are of genetic origin. Researches on Menkes and Wilson disorders have provided useful insights in the field of copper homeostasis and in particular into the understanding of intracellular trafficking and distribution of copper at mol. levels. Therapies based on metal supplementation with copper histidine or removal of copper excess by means of specific copper chelators are currently effective in treating MD and WD, resp. Copper chelation therapy is now attracting much attention for the investigation and treatment of various neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer, Parkinson and CreutzfeldtJakob. An excess of copper appears to be an essential co-factor for angiogenesis. Moreover, elevated levels of copper have been found in many types of human cancers, including prostate, breast, colon, lung, and brain. On these basis, the employment of copper chelators has been reported to be of therapeutic value in the treatment of several types of cancers as anti-angiogenic mols. More recently, mixts. of copper chelators with copper salts have been found to act as efficient proteasome inhibitors and apoptosis inducers, specifically in cancer cells. Moreover, following the worldwide success of platinum(II) compds. in cancer chemotherapy, several families of individual copper complexes have been studied as potential antitumor agents. These investigations, revealing the occurrence of mechanisms of action quite different from platinum drugs, head toward the development of new anticancer metallodrugs with improved specificity and decreased toxic side effects.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXos1Snuro%253D&md5=8f576825c072cd1e95c3675cd07c1dc8
    12. 12
      Nasulewicz, A.; Mazur, A.; Opolski, A. Role of copper in tumour angiogenesis—clinical implications. J. Trace Elem. Med. Biol. 2004, 18, 1– 8,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jtemb.2004.02.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Role of copper in tumor angiogenesis - clinical implications
      Nasulewicz, Anna; Mazur, Andrzej; Opolski, Adam
      Journal of Trace Elements in Medicine and Biology (2004), 18 (1), 1-8CODEN: JTEBFO; ISSN:0946-672X. (Elsevier GmbH)
      A review. The formation of new blood vessels is the initial step in progressive tumor development and metastasis. The first stage in tumor angiogenesis is the activation of endothelial cells. Copper ions stimulate proliferation and migration of endothelial cells. It has been shown that serum copper concn. increases as the cancer disease progresses and correlates with tumor incidence and burden. Copper ions also activate several proangiogenic factors, e.g., vascular endothelial growth factor, basic fibroblast growth factor, tumor necrosis factor alpha and interleukin 1. This review concerns a brief introduction into the basics of tumor blood vessel development as well as the regulatory mechanisms of this process. The role of copper ions in tumor angiogenesis is discussed. The new antiangiogenic therapies based on a redn. of copper levels in tumor microenvironment are reviewed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVensbbJ&md5=9993017fb5fc2c7e09a0efffbbfbc5d6

      Santini, C.; Pellei, M.; Gandin, V.; Porchia, M.; Tisato, F.; Marzano, C. Advances in copper complexes as anticancer agents. Chem. Rev. 2014, 114, 815– 862,  DOI: 10.1021/cr400135x
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Advances in Copper Complexes as Anticancer Agents
      Santini, Carlo; Pellei, Maura; Gandin, Valentina; Porchia, Marina; Tisato, Francesco; Marzano, Cristina
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 114 (1), 815-862CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      This review describes advances in the synthesis, design, and development of copper complexes as anticancer agents in the last 4 years. Interest in this field has rapidly grown in recent years, as illustrated by the increasing no. of publications reported since 2000. This summary covers the period 2008-2012 and follows the authors' previous efforts in the same area. Furthermore, the authors summarize recent findings on (i) identification of the main mol. targets and cellular pathways involved in the copper complexes-induced antiproliferative effects and (ii) the state of art of in vivo studies on the antitumor activity of copper compds. This overview would like to be a useful tool for the research community actively involved in the copper-based anticancer drug discovery.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFygurrL&md5=6d6fca30804d7b44c2079cf30327cfc3

      Franz, K. J. Application of inorganic chemistry for non-cancer therapeutics. Dalton Trans. 2012, 41, 6333– 6334,  DOI: 10.1039/c2dt90061k
